metadata.title: Alkaline-doped multiwall carbon nanotubes as efficient catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation

Editor's choice paper Alkaline-doped multiwall carbon nanotubes as efficient catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation F.J. Delgado-Gómez a b V. Calvino-Casilda c A. Cerpa-Naranjo a M.L. Rojas-Cervantes b ⁎ a Departamento de Ingeniería Industrial y Aeroespacial, Escuela de Ingeniería, Arquitectura y Diseño, Universidad Europea de Madrid, c/Tajo s/n, Villaviciosa de Odón 28670 Madrid, Spain Departamento de Ingeniería Industrial y Aeroespacial Escuela de Ingeniería Arquitectura y Diseño Universidad Europea de Madrid c/Tajo s/n Villaviciosa de Odón Madrid 28670 Spain b Departamento de Química Inorgánica y Química Técnica, Facultad de Ciencias, UNED, Paseo Senda del Rey n° 9, Madrid 28040, Spain Departamento de Química Inorgánica y Química Técnica Facultad de Ciencias UNED Paseo Senda del Rey n° 9 Madrid 28040 Spain c Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Electrónica, Control, Telemática y Química Aplicada a la Ingeniería, ETS de Ingenieros Industriales, UNED, c/Juan del Rosal 2, Madrid 28040, Spain Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Electrónica, Control Telemática y Química Aplicada a la Ingeniería ETS de Ingenieros Industriales UNED c/Juan del Rosal 2 Madrid 28040 Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of alkaline doped multiwall carbon nanotubes, CNTOM (with M=Li, Na, K, Cs) has been prepared by wetness impregnation with alkaline acetates and subsequent pyrolysis of commercial multiwall carbon nanotubes previously oxidized with nitric acid, characterized by different physico-chemical techniques and tested as catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and different active methylene compounds. As determined by different techniques, caesium has been incorporated in a less extent than the rest of alkalines. The SBET values decrease in the CNTOM with respect to the raw material, mainly due to the blockage of micropores and small mesopores by the metallic phase formed. As deduced from PZC values, the character of the surface of nanotubes changes from acid for the oxidized sample to basic for the alkaline doped nanotubes, the basic character decreasing with the size of the alkaline cation. The order of activity observed in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate seems to be correlated mainly with the amount of basic centres, CNTOCs being the less active catalyst due to its lower metal content. Conversion values of benzaldehyde comprised between 67 and 89% were achieved in only 120min. Keywords Alkaline-doped carbon nanotubes Knoevenagel condensation Textural properties 1 Introduction In the last decades, research in porous carbon nanomaterials and their application in the field of modern science and technology have aroused special interest and particularly, the manufacture and functionalization of carbon nanotubes (CNT), whose purpose is to achieve the control of surface properties (e.g. acidity-basicity, adsorption and wettability) and also those of the bulk. The exceptional electronic, chemical, and mechanical properties [1–3] of CNT, make them suitable materials for use in different research fields, including catalysis [4,5]. In order to be applied as catalysts, their physicochemical and surface properties can be modified by incorporating heteroatoms or functionalities in their structures. In this way, the incorporation of nitrogen atoms to CNT has led to the development of materials with enhanced basic properties [6,7], caused by the anchoring of nitrogen in the basal planes of the carbon nanotubes [8,9]. Another via to introduce basic functionalities in the nanotubes is the formation of nanohybrides by blending carbon nanotubes and metal oxides of basic character, such as MgO, ZnO, TiO2, and Mg-Al or Ce-Zr mixed oxides [10]. Our research group has a wide experience in the synthesis of alkaline carbons, starting from carbonaceous materials of both vegetable (e.g. activated carbons) and synthetic origin (e.g. prepared by sol-gel method of polymerization of resorcinol with formaldehyde, following the method proposed by Pekala [11]). These alkaline carbons were successfully applied as base catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation [12,13], the synthesis of α,β-unsaturated nitriles [14], the N-alkylation of imidazole with different alkylating agents [15], and the synthesis of 1,4 dihydropyridines [16]. The use of carbon nanotubes doped with nitrogen as base catalysts has been reported in the literature for some reactions, such as Knoevenagel condensation [17,18], transesterification of triglycerides [19] and aldol condensations [7,20]. Some catalysts based on metal nanoparticles anchored to carbon nanotubes have been also used. These metals are palladium for the synthesis of N-containing heterocycles [21], nickel for synthesizing pyrimidone heterocycles [22], and cobalt for the synthesis of dihydroquinoxalines [23]. However, up to our knowledge there are no studies in the literature describing the use of carbon nanotubes doped with alkaline metals in carbon-carbon bond forming reactions such as the Knoevenagel condensation, widely used for the synthesis of key intermediates and final products. Usually, the Knoevenagel condensation is performed between ketones or aldehydes and compounds with active methylene groups, in the presence of several catalysts, both homogeneous and heterogeneous, such as piperidine [24], ionic liquids [25], Lewis acid catalysts [26], zeolites [27], alkali modified metal oxides [28], and mesoporous materials [29], among others. Nevertheless, the research to find novel catalysts for the CC bond Knoevenagel reaction still arouses great interest in the field of organic synthesis. Considering all the above mentioned, herein this work presents for the first time the synthesis and characterization of basic catalysts based on CNT functionalized by oxidation in acid media and then, doped with Li, Na, K and Cs species to be applied in Knoevenagel reactions. The catalysts were characterized by different techniques in order to identify the influence of the oxidative functionalization, the pyrolysis and the metallic phase incorporated in the nanotubes on their textural and crystalline properties and on their catalytic activity. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts 2.1.1 Preparation of oxidized carbon nanotubes Multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) provided by Sigma-Aldrich, with OD×L 6–9nm×5μm and purity >95% were used as raw material for the preparation of the catalysts. The MWCNTs, named as CNT herein, were submitted to a procedure of oxidation with nitric acid as follows. 3g of the as-received CNT were dispersed in 250mL of the nitric acid (65wt%) in a 500mL round bottom flask equipped with a condenser and the dispersion was refluxed at 120°C for 16h. After that, the resulting dispersion was diluted with 300mL of water and filtered. The solid thus obtained was washed up and centrifuged several times until neutral pH, and finally dried at room temperature for 72h. The resulting sample was named as CNTO. 2.1.2 Preparation of alkaline doped carbon nanotubes The CNTO was crushed and sieved to a 0.05<d<0.10mm particle size. CNTO sample was doped with alkaline metals by incipient wetness impregnation method. A solution of the corresponding alkaline acetate, in the appropriate molar concentrations in order to obtain a metal loading of 6wt% were added drop to drop to 0.85g of CNTO. The solid obtained was dried at room temperature for 24h, dried at 60°C for 16h and finally pyrolyzed under nitrogen flow of 100mL/min at 500°C for 5h in order to decompose the alkaline acetate salt. The pyrolyzed samples were designed as CNTOM (where M=Li, Na, K, Cs). For comparison, the oxidized nanotubes without impregnation treatment were also pyrolyzed, obtaining the CNTOp sample. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The textural characterization of all samples was accomplished by nitrogen adsorption. The adsorption isotherms for N2 at −196°C were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 equipment. Prior to the adsorption measurements, the samples were outgassed at 150°C for 8h until a vacuum set point of 200μm Hg. The specific surface area and the micropore size distribution were calculated by the BET method and the t-plot method, respectively [30]. The mesopore size distribution, as well as the mesopore volume and the average mesopore diameter, were determined by the BJH method. Thermal analysis (TG-DTA) of CNT, CNTOp and CNTOM samples was carried out using a Seiko SSC 5200 TG-DTA 320 System. Samples of about 15mg were heated in air from 30 up to 1000°C (flow rate=100mL/min) with a heating rate of 10°C/min. Infrared spectra of CNT, CNTO, CNTOp and CNTOM samples were measured in a FT-IR Vector 22 Bruker instrument, equipped with ATR analyzer of germanium (MiracleTM Single Reflection ATR, Pike) in the 4000–700cm−1 range. TEM images of the samples were recorded by using a JEOL 2100 microscope operating at 200kV and by X-Ray diffraction using a X’Pert Pro Panalytical diffractometer with CuKα radiation (1.5406Å), operating at 40kV and 40mA. The point of zero charge (PZC) measurements were carried out following the procedure described by Valente-Nabais and Carrot [31], holding a mixture of 0.1M sodium nitrate and 7wt% of the carbonaceous solid at 25°C for 48h. After this time, the samples were filtered and the pH of the corresponding filtrate was measured in a CRISON model GLP–22pH meter. 2.3 Catalytic activity In a typical experiment, an equimolecular mixture of benzaldehyde and the active methylene compound (14mmol for ethyl cyanoacetate, pKa=9, and 9mmol for ethyl acetoacetate, pKa=10.7), was placed in a three-necked reactor on a multi-experiment work station StarFish, equipped with thermometer. The reaction was carried out under inert atmosphere and in absence of any solvent at 90°C, under continuous magnetic stirring using 1wt% of catalyst for the condensation of pKa=9, and 2wt% of catalyst for the condensation of pKa=10.7. The evolution of the reaction was followed by gas chromatography (Agilent 6890 GC), analysing the reaction samples taken periodically from the batch reactor. Before the analysis, the catalyst was separated from the reaction samples by filtration. Once the reaction was completed, the catalyst was washed with acetone several times and dried at 100°C for 24h to be reused in a new cycle of reaction, in which the sampling was carried out twice at two different reaction times, i.e., 120 and 240min. Due to the slight loss of catalyst amount produced between one cycle and the following one, the reactant amounts were rescaled in order to keep constant the catalyst/reactants ratio. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization With the aim of quantifying the amount of alkaline metal incorporated in the oxidized nanotubes and to study how it influences their thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis of pyrolyzed nanotubes were carried out in air (see Fig. 1 ). For comparison, analysis of CNT, CNTO and CNTOp were also carried out. The raw CNT sample decomposes in a very narrow range of temperature (400–510°C). According to the literature [32,33], the amorphous carbon and the carbon nanoparticles decompose in the 150–400°C range and the nanotubes structure do it in the 400–600°C region. The absence of any loss in the TG curve of CNT sample at lower temperature seems to indicate that the presence of amorphous carbon in the commercial nanotubes is very scarce or almost null. When the CNT sample is treated with nitric acid, the profile of the corresponding TG curve changes. The weight loss observed in the TG curve for CNTO, from room temperature up to 150°C, is due to the removal of water molecules. In the range between 150 and 500°C, the weight loss is associated with the oxidation of different functional groups containing oxygen (carboxylic, aldehyde, etc.), which are produced at the surface of the carbonaceous fractions not forming part of the nanotubes [34]. In the CNTO sample, the oxidation of the fraction corresponding to the nanotubes occurs at a higher temperature (500–620°C) than in the raw nanotubes, which evidences the higher thermal stability of the nanotubes after their treatment with nitric acid. The TG curve of CNT leads to a residue of 1.4wt%, due to metallic impurities resulting of the method used for the preparation of commercial nanotubes. According to the results of XRD (see below) this metallic phase corresponds to CoCu2Sn phase. The treatment with nitric acid led to the partial removal of metallic impurities, resulting therefore in a lower residue content (0.9wt% for CNTO). In the TG curve of CNTOp the weight loss corresponding to the oxygenated groups is not detected since they must have been removed during the pyrolysis process, and a very fast oxidation occurs in the range 500–620°C, leading to a residue of 0.56wt%. In the CNTOM samples, the oxidation process of the nanotubes occurs at a lower temperature than that of CNTOp, around 125°C lower in the case of CNTOLi and approximately 200°C for the rest of alkaline nanotubes, suggesting that the metallic phase contributes to the destabilization of the nanotubes by promoting their oxidation. The oxidation in air of alkaline nanotubes produces higher values of residue than in CNTO, as expected, due to the presence of the alkaline metal incorporated in the nanotubes (see Table 1 ). Thus, the residue values were 13.5wt% for Li, 8.9wt% for Na, 7.6wt% for K, and 4.0wt% for Cs. The weight loss observed above 700°C in the TG curves of NTCOM samples could be due to the decomposition of the metallic phases present as carbonate (see XRD results) in the corresponding oxides. By assuming that the final residue corresponds to the content in oxide M2O, the measured metal amounts were very close to the theoretical ones, with the exception of caesium, which was incorporated only in approximately the half of the theoretical amount. Therefore, the impregnation with the caesium acetate seems to have occurred in a less extent than for the rest of the salts. The textural properties of the samples are given in Table 2 , together with the PZC values. The carbon nanotubes possess a cylindrical structure and the major contribution to the porosity proceeds mainly from the void space between the bundles, resulting in lower surface areas compared to other carbon materials. From the values of Vmeso and Vmic shown in Table 2 it is deduced that the CNT under study are solid mesoporous. The raw CNT show a mesopore volume (20–500Å) of 0.530cm3/g and a specific surface area of 248m2/g, this value being very similar to that reported in the literature for other commercial MWCNTs, ranging between 212 and 271m2/g [35–37]. There is some controversy in the literature about how the oxidation treatment with nitric acid affects the textural characteristics (pore volume, surface area) of CNT. Some authors have found that the oxidation treatment leads to an increment of the surface area, due to the removal of amorphous carbon, monocrystalline graphite, fullerenes and impurities of the surface [38,39] and also because a shortening of the nanotubes [40] and an opening of the tips occur [41,42]. On the contrary, other authors have reported that the pore volume, associated mainly with the void space between the nanotubes [43], decreases when the material is treated with nitric acid, because a de-agglomeration of the nanotubes occurs as a consequence of their oxidation [44]. In addition, a blockage of the pore entries takes place due to the presence of functional groups formed during the oxidation [45,46]. In this work, a slight decrease in the surface area and pore volume is produced after oxidation of CNT, similarly to that reported previously [36,37]. The de-agglomeration of nanotubes, which might be produced as a consequence of the oxidation, can be corroborated by TEM images (see results below), where a higher dispersion of nanotubes is observed for the CNTO sample than for the CNT. In addition, the presence of functional groups, which could produce the blockage of the pore entries, can be corroborated by the weight loss detected in the 150–500°C range in the TG curve of the CNTO sample obtained in air. The pyrolysis of the oxidized nanotubes can lead to the removal of the oxygen functionalities, producing a development of meso- ad micro porosity. Notice that the values of Smic and Vmic for CNTOp are almost the double than those for CNTO (see Table 2). When the CNTO is impregnated with alkaline acetates, some of the micropores generated during the pyrolysis are blocked by the alkaline cations anchored to the carbonate or bicarbonate groups, not being accessible to the nitrogen, and therefore producing a decrease in the Smic and Vmic values of the impregnated nanotubes. The decrease is more accused in the case of CNTOLi and CNTONa samples, which seems to indicate that the interaction between Li and Na cations and the walls of nanotubes has occurred in a major extent than in the case of the other cations. In fact, for CNTOLi, the Smic value is null and all the contribution to the SBET value comes from external surface area. As a consequence, the values of SBET areas for CNTOM, comprised between 150 and 230m2/g, are lower than that for CNTOp. Fig. 2 displays the BJH distribution (adsorption branch) of the nanotubes. It can be observed that the CNT sample shows a very low amount of mesopores in the 2–20nm range, containing mainly mesopores of bigger size and macropores, as deduced by the continuous increment produced from 30nm. The oxidation process leads to a de-agglomeration of bundles, generating more mesopores of size >10nm, corresponding to the void spaces between the bundles. In addition, an increase in the volume of mesopores between 2 and 10nm occurs, due to the tips opening and shortening of the nanotubes. The pyrolysis causes the removal of oxygen functionalities that could block the entry to the nanotubes and void spaces, producing an increment in the mesopore volume. Furthermore, the pyrolysis also generates the formation of new mesopores of smaller size, absent in CNTO, as seen in the peak centred at 3.2nm in the BJH curve of CNTOp. This peak is not observed in the BJH curves of CNTOM (with M=Li, Na, K), probably because these smaller mesopores are blocked by the metallic carbonate or bicarbonate phases formed, as detected by XRD, whose crystallite sizes, determined by Scherrer equation, are in this order (see results below). These metallic phases could also block the void space between nanotubes, as seen by the decrease in the height of the BJH curves of CNTOM in the pores of size >10nm. On the contrary, the BJH curve for CNTOCs is different from those corresponding to the rest of CNTOM samples, and very similar to that of CNTOp, showing the peak centred around 3.2nm, which seems to indicate, again, a lower interaction between the caesium cations and the nanotubes walls during the impregnation process. In summary, the changes produced in the textural properties show that the interaction of the alkaline ions and the walls of nanotubes has occurred, leading mainly to a blockage of micropores and small mesopores by the metallic phase. In the case of Cs, this interaction has been produced in a lower extent. ATR-FTIR spectroscopy is a very useful tool for studying the functional groups attached to the sidewalls of CNT. The ATR-FTIR spectra for CNT, CNTO and CNTOp samples are displayed in Fig. 3 . In all three spectra, a band centred around 1550cm−1, corresponding to CC vibrations of the skeleton of CNT, is observed [47,48]. In the spectra of the oxidized nanotubes and their corresponding pyrolyzed, a band centred at 1715cm−1, assigned to CO stretching vibrations in COOH groups, is detected [47,49]. This band decreases in intensity in the case of CNTOp, indicating a lower presence of these groups, which have been removed partially during the pyrolysis. The presence of carboxylic groups after treatment with nitric acid is also corroborated by the appearance of a band around 1160cm−1, associated with CO stretching vibrations [48,50], and also by a shoulder centred at 1410cm−1, corresponding to OH bending deformations [48]. The infrared spectra of the alkaline nanotubes are depicted in Fig. 4 . When comparing with the spectrum of CNTOp, the appearing of new bands and the shift of the existing ones can be observed, indicating that the interaction between the alkaline cations and the walls of nanotubes has occurred. The band assigned to the CC vibration (1550–1560cm−1) is detected in all the spectra, although for NTCOLi appears as a shoulder. For this sample, two new bands placed at 1420 and 1470cm−1 assigned to antisymmetric stretch of the carbonate groups (phase detected by XRD, see below) are observed. A band of lower intensity located at 860cm−1 could be also due to the out-of-plane bend of the carbonate groups. The bands associated to the carbonate (1430, 860cm−1) are also present in the spectrum of CNTONa. For the sample doped with potassium, the existence of the bicarbonate species is confirmed by the bands placed at 1010, 970 and 830cm−1. In the ATR-FTIR spectrum of CNTOK, an additional band at 1625cm−1 is detected, which could be assigned to CO groups in quinone structures, formed as an intermediate in the oxidation process [48] and a band at 1010cm−1 associated with COC stretching vibrations in ether functionalities [48]. By last, the FTIR spectrum of CNTOCs is very similar to that of CNTOp, indicating that the interaction between the caesium cations and the walls of nanotubes has been produced in a less extent than for the rest of alkaline cations, as found by other techniques. Further studies of molecular dynamics simulation will be carried out in a subsequent work in order to explain this behaviour. The diffractograms for the CNT, CNTO and CNTOp samples are displayed in Fig. 5 a. In the diffraction pattern of CNT, together with the peaks corresponding to hexagonal graphite (JCPDS-ICDD 01-075-1621) some metallic impurities, from the method of preparation of the commercial CNT, are detected. These impurities, assigned to the CoCu2Sn phase (JCPDS-ICDD 00-029-0467) disappear after the treatment with nitric acid, as observed in the corresponding diffractograms of CNTO and CNTOp samples. After the impregnation with the alkaline acetates and the pyrolysis of the oxidized nanotubes, the presence of some metallic phases is detected (see Fig. 5b). Thus, the phases corresponding to the carbonates, Li2CO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 00-001-0996, crystallite size of 24.4nm) and Na2CO3 (JCPDS-ICDD 00-001-116, crystallite size of 20.6nm) are detected in the CNTOLi and CNTONa samples, respectively. In the case of CNTOK, the bicarbonate phase, KHCO3, (JCPDS-ICDD 00-001-0976, crystallite size of 30.7nm) is formed. However, in the diffractogram of CNTOCs, no metallic phase is detected. The lower amount of Cs incorporated (as determined by TG analysis) may be responsible for a higher dispersion and the formation of crystallite size lower than 4nm, not being detected by XRD technique. Carbon nanotubes can be observed in the TEM micrograph of CNT (Fig. 6 a). They are also observed in the image of CNTO (Fig. 6b); however, the nanotubes are visibly shorter and more dispersed, less grouped in bundles. As the oxidation advances, more nanotubes pass into the solution, and the agglomerations are disaggregated [44]. The treatment of pyrolysis of the CNTO sample (Fig. 6c) and of the samples impregnated with the alkaline salts (Fig. 6d, CNTONa image is shown in a representative way) leads to the formation of a large fraction of amorphous carbon. The PZC values of the samples are given in Table 2. The commercial CNT have a surface almost neutral (PZC=6.4), which is functionalized by treatment with nitric acid, resulting in the formation of some oxygenated groups, mainly carboxylic groups, lowering the PZC value in more than 4 unities (see PZC value for CNTO sample). The process of pyrolysis leads to the removal of some of these functional groups and the PZC value of the surface increases up to 4.6. For CNTOM samples, the PZC values are much higher (PZC>7) than for CNTO, which proves the anchoring of the alkaline metals to the surface of nanotubes. It could be explained in terms of an electrostatic interaction between the alkaline cations and the carboxylate groups of the surface, turning after pyrolysis into carbonate or bicarbonate species that confers basic character to the CNT surface. The order of basicity of the alkaline metals is Cs>K>Na>Li. However, as observed in Table 2, CNTOLi and CNTONa display the highest values of PZC, above 10, due probably to the most basic character of carbonate species with respect to the bicarbonate ones (K1(H2CO3)=4.35·10−7; K2(H2CO3)=4.69·10−11), present in CNTOK sample (PZC=9.1). Furthermore, the sample doped with caesium, NTCOCs, shows the lowest PZC value of the CNTOM samples, in spite of the strongest basic character of caesium cation, which confirms the least incorporation of this metal into the CNT, as found by TG analysis. 3.2 Catalytic activity Knoevenagel reaction can progress successfully using basic catalysts or acid-basic catalysts. Both, basic centres and acid-base centres promote the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, playing a key role. Usually, the Knoevenagel condensation is performed between aldehydes or ketones and active methylene compounds. The mechanism of the Knoevenagel reaction in the presence of basic catalysts is very well reported in literature. Basic sites, in our case provided by the alkaline metals, abstract a proton from the methylene group of the methylene compound (ethyl cyanoacetate and ethyl acetoacetate), forming a carbanion. This carbanion attacks the carbonyl group of benzaldehyde, which is protonated forming a hydroxyl group. Finally, the dehydration of this compound leads to the formation of a CC bond (the Knoevenagel product) and water. In the present work, the Knoevenagel condensation has been carried out between benzaldehyde and different methylenic compounds, such as ethyl cyanoacetate (pKa =9) and ethyl acetoacetate (pKa =10.7) (see Scheme 1 ). Fig. 7 shows the results obtained in terms of conversion (%) of benzaldehyde in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate over CNTOM samples. This figure reveals that the reaction can proceed effectively over carbon nanotubes when alkaline cations are anchored in them. In case of CNTO and CNTOp samples (not shown in Fig. 7), the catalytic activity observed for both of them was almost negligible. Therefore, the functionalization by oxidation treatment did not increase the activity of the CNT, whereas the anchoring of alkaline metals on CNTO endows these materials with activity in the Knoevenagel condensation, generating basic centres capable of abstracting the proton from the methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate and release the reaction. As expected, the catalytic activity of all the CNTOM samples increased regularly as the reaction progressed. After 120min of reaction time the conversion of benzaldehyde increased more slowly, which means that the stationary state has been reached. Ethyl(2E)-2-cyano-3-phenyl-2-propenoate was the only reaction product obtained in all cases. The order of catalytic activity observed was: K>Na>Li>Cs. According to the basic character of the alkaline metals, the order expected should be Cs>K>Na>Li. However, the lower activity observed for CNTOCs could be probably due to its lower metal content (as shown by TG analysis), which determines its less number of basic centres, as confirmed by its lower PZC value (see Table 2). It has been broadly discussed in the literature [29,51] the influence of the porous structure of other materials over their catalytic behaviour in the Knoevenagel condensation; however, this fact was not observed in the present work. Moreover the mesopores present in the samples are of size enough (average diameters of 9.8–14.2nm, see Table 1) to enable the confinement of the reactants and avoid the appearance of diffusional problems. Therefore, the catalytic activity seems to depend solely on the basic character of the alkaline cation and the amount of these basic centres incorporated to the CNTs. The values of catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation (pKa =9) were calculated in terms of yields (mol/g cath) in order to be compared with data from literature. The values of yields obtained at 60min, comprised between 0.230 (for CNTOLi) and 0.380mol/gh (for CNTOCs) are one magnitude order higher than those reported, 0.045mol/gh in [52] and 0.017mol/g·h in [17], for nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes at 80°C at the same reaction time using similar reaction conditions. Furthermore, they are still higher than the obtained by Fujita et al. [18] with a N-carbon doped material prepared by calcination and ammoxidation of a commercial polyacrylonitrile (0.199mol/gh). Therefore, the alkaline doped carbon nanotubes prepared for the first time in the present work provide new and current opportunities as heterogeneous basic catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation. In order to study the stability of the catalysts, experiments of recycling were carried out. The catalysts were tested in three successive cycles of reusability, without showing significant loss of activity. As an example, the conversion value of benzaldehyde in the reaction with ethyl cyanoacetate at 240min decreased from 92.1% for the first cycle to 90.8% for the third one when CNTONa was used as catalyst. In order to study the stability of the catalysts, experiments of recycling were carried out by testing the two more active catalysts in three successive cycles. The results (see Fig. 8 ) show that for CNTONa no significant loss of activity is produced, and the conversion value of benzaldehyde in the reaction with ethyl cyanoacetate at 240min decreased slightly from 92.1% for the first cycle to 90.8% for the third one. In the case of CNTOK, the conversion value is kept in the second cycle, although the catalyst shows a loss of the 12% in the activity in the third cycle for the longest reaction time. This could be caused by a little leaching of potassium or by a deactivation of the active sites due to the adsorption of the organic products on them. The CNTOM samples were also active in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and a methylene compound with a higher pKa, ethyl acetoacetate (pKa =10.7). Fig. 9 shows the conversion of benzaldehyde values obtained. Similar to the catalytic behaviour observed for the Knoevenagel condensation of pKa =9, CNTOK was the most active catalyst and CNTOLi the least active catalyst. However, in this case, other sub-products are formed alongside the Knoevenagel condensation product, due to the existence of secondary reactions such as decarboxylation of the Knoevenagel product, aldolic condensations of the methylenic ester and oxidation of benzaldehyde, among others. As expected, the catalytic activity of the samples systematically increased with the reaction time, reaching conversion values of up to 64%, in case of the most active catalyst, CNTOK. Contrary, the selectivity to the Knoevenagel product (Fig. 10 ) decreased with reaction time and more sharply for the samples with the highest PZC values.Thus, the selectivity value of 100% observed at 15min decreased to 93% for CNTOCs, 69% for CNTOK, and 49% for CNTONa, after 240min. In the case of CNTOLi, the selectivity diminished from 85% to 24%. After the above considerations, it seems that the nature of metal and the basic strength of the centres strongly influences the selectivity in the Knoevenagel condensation of methylene compounds with a higher pKa (ethyl acetoacetate; pKa =10.7), the selectivity order being the same as observed for the basicity of the corresponding alkaline metal, i.e. Cs>K>Na>Li. 4 Conclusions The present study demonstrates for the first time that carbon nanotubes oxidized and doped with alkaline metals are attractive catalysts for classical organic synthetic reactions, such as the Knoevenagel condensation. As determined by different characterization techniques, the interaction of the alkaline and the carbon nanotubes has been produced in all cases, although in a less extent for CNTOCs. All the solids are mesoporous materials; the oxidation of CNT produces a decrease of SBET surface area and pore volume, due to the blockage of pores by oxygen functionalities, which are removed by pyrolysis. The SBET values also decrease in the CNTOM with respect to the raw material, mainly due to the blockage of micropores and small mesopores by the metallic phase formed. Conversion values of benzaldehyde of 87% and 100% selectivity to the Knoevenagel condensation product were achieved for the most active catalysts, i.e. CNTONa and CNTOK, in only 120min when using ethyl cyanoacetate as methylene compound. The key factor in the catalytic activity seems to be the presence of basic sites with strength enough to abstract the proton of the methylene compound and release the reaction. The pore size of the CNTOM samples seems to be suitable to produce the confinement of the reactants and the release of the products without any diffusional problem. In addition, these basic carbon materials were prepared following an easy procedure and a simple work-up and their application as catalysts could be extended to other CC forming reactions in the field or organic synthesis. coredata.dc:description: A series of alkaline doped multiwall carbon nanotubes, CNTOM (with M=Li, Na, K, Cs) has been prepared by wetness impregnation with alkaline acetates and subsequent pyrolysis of commercial multiwall carbon nanotubes previously oxidized with nitric acid, characterized by different physico-chemical techniques and tested as catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and different active methylene compounds. As determined by different techniques, caesium has been incorporated in a less extent than the rest of alkalines. The SBET values decrease in the CNTOM with respect to the raw material, mainly due to the blockage of micropores and small mesopores by the metallic phase formed. As deduced from PZC values, the character of the surface of nanotubes changes from acid for the oxidized sample to basic for the alkaline doped nanotubes, the basic character decreasing with the size of the alkaline cation. The order of activity observed in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate seems to be correlated mainly with the amount of basic centres, CNTOCs being the less active catalyst due to its lower metal content. Conversion values of benzaldehyde comprised between 67 and 89% were achieved in only 120min.
coredata.dc:title: Alkaline-doped multiwall carbon nanotubes as efficient catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation
